natural solution: Applying the logarithmic identities $\log_a b^c=c\log_a b$ and $\log_{a^c} b=(1/c) \log_a b$, we find \begin{align} 10 &= \log_4 x + \log_2 x^2 \\ &= \log_4 x + 2 \log_2 x \\ &= \log_{2^2} x + 2 \log_2 x \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \log_2 x + 2 \log_2 x \\ &= \frac{5}{2} \log_2 x. \end{align}Therefore, $\log_2 x = 4$, which implies $x = 2^4 = \boxed{16}$.
